content.text: Once upon a time, in a quiet little village nestled between rolling green hills and a sparkling blue river, there lived a dog named Bruno.
Bruno was not just any dog—he was strong, clever, and had the shiniest coat in the whole village.
But Bruno had one big problem: he was *very* greedy.
Every morning, Bruno would trot down to the village square, where the kind baker, Mr.
Thompson, would leave out scraps of bread and meat for the stray animals.
Bruno always pushed the other dogs and cats aside, gobbling up the biggest pieces before anyone else could have a bite.
"Mine, mine, all mine!" he would bark, wagging his tail proudly as he chewed.
One sunny afternoon, as Bruno was sniffing around the marketplace, he spotted something that made his eyes grow wide with excitement.
There, hanging from a butcher’s stall, was the biggest, juiciest bone he had ever seen!
It was so plump and meaty that Bruno’s mouth began to water just looking at it.
"That bone is *perfect*," he thought.
"And it’s going to be *all mine*!"  Without a second thought, Bruno snatched the bone in his teeth and dashed away from the marketplace.
He didn’t even stop to say thank you to the butcher, who had been kind enough to leave it out for the animals.
Instead, he ran as fast as his paws could carry him, eager to enjoy his prize in peace.
Bruno trotted along the riverbank, his tail held high.
The sun was beginning to set, painting the sky in shades of pink and gold, and the water shimmered like a sheet of glass.
"This is the perfect spot," Bruno said to himself. "No one will bother me here.

I can eat my bone in peace, and maybe—just maybe—I’ll save a little for later." (Though, deep down, he knew he would probably eat it all at once.)  As he settled down on the soft grass, Bruno looked at his reflection in the still water.
To his surprise, he saw another dog staring back at him—one with a bone *even bigger* than his own!
Bruno’s eyes widened. "That dog has a bone twice as big as mine!" he growled.
"I want *that* one instead!"  Without thinking, Bruno barked at the dog in the water.
"Give me that bone, you thief!" he snarled.
But the dog in the water only barked back, just as fiercely. Bruno’s ears flattened against his head.
"Oh no, you don’t!" he snapped.
"That bone is *mine*!"  Determined to take the other dog’s bone, Bruno lunged forward—*SPLASH!*—right into the river.
The moment he opened his mouth to grab the bone, his own slipped from his jaws and sank into the water.
The reflection vanished, and Bruno was left spluttering in the cold river, his prize gone forever.
"Where—where did it go?" Bruno whimpered, paddling frantically.
He searched and searched, but the bone was nowhere to be found.
The other dogs from the village, who had been watching from a distance, began to laugh.
"Serves you right, Bruno!" they barked. "You were so greedy, you lost everything!"  Bruno hung his head in shame.
He dragged himself out of the river, his fur dripping wet, and slunk back to the village.
The other animals gave him sympathetic looks, but no one offered him any food.
After all, why should they help a dog who had never shared a single bite?
That night, as Bruno curled up in his usual spot behind the bakery, his stomach growled with hunger.
He thought about how he had pushed the other animals away, how he had taken more than his fair share, and how he had lost his precious bone because of his greed.
For the first time, he felt truly sorry.
The next morning, Bruno woke up early and trotted to the village square. Mr.
Thompson had just set out a fresh batch of scraps, and the other animals were already gathered around.
But this time, Bruno didn’t shove his way to the front.
Instead, he waited patiently, letting the smaller dogs and cats eat first.
When it was finally his turn, he took only a small piece of bread and a sliver of meat.
The other animals watched in surprise. "Bruno?" asked a little terrier named Pip.
"Aren’t you going to take more?"  Bruno shook his head. "No, Pip. I’ve learned my lesson.
There’s enough for everyone if we share." And with that, he trotted off to find a quiet spot to enjoy his meal—this time, without any greed in his heart.
From that day on, Bruno was no longer the greedy dog of the village.
He shared his food, played fairly with the other animals, and even helped those who were hungry.
And though he never found another bone as big as the one he had lost, he discovered something far more valuable: the joy of kindness and the warmth of friendship.
And so, Bruno lived happily ever after, his belly full not just with food, but with happiness too.
